title: Two Truths and a Lie
description: A classic icebreaker game where participants share three statements about themselves - two true and one false. Others must guess which statement is the lie. This game helps team members get to know each other better while creating a relaxed and fun atmosphere.
shortDescription: Share three statements, one is false, let others guess
steps: Have all participants sit in a circle or gather together
Explain the rules: each person shares three statements about themselves, two true and one false
The first person shares their three statements
Other participants discuss and vote on which one is false
The speaker reveals the correct answer and shares the story behind it
Continue in order until everyone has shared
tips: Encourage participants to share interesting or surprising facts
Host should create a relaxed atmosphere to avoid pressure
Set time limits to keep the game moving
variants: Online version: Use video conferencing tools, participants can vote in chat
Quick version: Each person only says two statements, one true and one false
Themed version: Limit statements to specific topics like childhood experiences or travel stories
objectives: Help team members get to know each other

title: Human Knot
description: Participants stand in a circle and randomly grab hands with others, forming a complex human knot. The team must untangle the knot through communication and collaboration without letting go of hands. This classic game tests teamwork and communication skills.
shortDescription: Team collaboration to untangle the human knot
steps: Have all participants stand in a tight circle
Each person extends their right hand and grabs another person's hand (not adjacent)
Then extend left hand and grab a different person's hand
Now you have formed a complex human knot
Team must untangle the knot through ducking, stepping over, and turning without letting go
Final goal is to form one or more circles
tips: Remind participants to be safe and gentle with movements
Encourage team members to communicate actively and suggest solutions
If the knot is too complex, allow one release and re-grip opportunity
variants: Increased difficulty: Require complete silence throughout
Competition version: Multiple groups compete to see who untangles fastest

title: 60-Second Introduction
description: Each participant has 60 seconds to introduce themselves, sharing their name, role, hobbies, or an interesting fact. This game is simple and efficient, perfect for quick icebreaking.
steps: Host explains the rules: each person has 60 seconds to introduce themselves
Can share name, role, hobbies, or an interesting fact
Start in order, host keeps time
When time is up, politely remind the next person
After everyone introduces, can have brief Q&A
tips: Inform participants in advance so they can prepare
Create a relaxed atmosphere to avoid nervousness
Host can demonstrate first
variants: Themed introduction: Limit content like my superpower or my dream
Picture introduction: Participants share a photo representing themselves and explain
objectives: Quickly get to know team members

title: Desert Island Survival
description: Participants imagine being stranded on a desert island and can only bring three items. Each person shares their choices and reasons, revealing personal values and priorities.
shortDescription: Choose three items for a desert island, share reasons
steps: Host sets the scene: you are stranded on a desert island
Each person can bring three items (excluding food and water)
Give participants 2-3 minutes to think
Each person shares their choices and reasons in turn
Others can ask questions or comment
Discuss the values behind different choices
tips: Encourage creative thinking
Avoid judging others' choices
Can guide discussion on importance of teamwork
variants: Time machine version: If you could go to past or future, what would you bring
Team version: Entire team can only bring three items, must reach consensus

title: Word Association
description: Participants form a circle, first person says a word, next person says a related word, and so on. This game quickly energizes the atmosphere and exercises reaction skills.
shortDescription: Quickly say related words, energize atmosphere
steps: Participants form a circle or sit in order
First person says a word (like sun)
Next person quickly says a related word (like warm)
Continue the chain, cannot repeat words already said
If someone pauses more than 3 seconds or repeats, they are out
Continue until only one person remains
tips: Keep a fast pace to increase fun
Can set themes like only animals or food
Create a relaxed atmosphere, don't be too serious
variants: Antonym version: Say the opposite of the previous word
First letter version: Next word must start with last letter of previous word

title: Find Common Ground
description: Participants split into small groups and find commonalities among all group members within a time limit. This game helps team members discover similarities and increase understanding.
shortDescription: Find commonalities among all group members
steps: Divide participants into groups of 3-5 people
Give each group 5-10 minutes
Group members discuss and find commonalities among everyone
Commonalities can be interests, experiences, preferences, etc.
Record at least 5 commonalities
Each group shares their findings
Discuss how these commonalities can help teamwork
tips: Encourage finding unique or interesting commonalities
Avoid too superficial commonalities (like we are all human)
Can set rewards to motivate groups to find more commonalities
variants: Difference version: Find unique characteristics of each person
Competition version: See which group finds the most commonalities

title: Emoji Story
description: Participants use emojis to tell a story or describe their day, others guess the content. This creative game is perfect for online meetings.
shortDescription: Tell stories with emojis, others guess
steps: Host explains rules: tell a story using emojis
First person sends a string of emojis in chat
Others guess the story content
Storyteller reveals answer and explains
Take turns, everyone gets a chance to tell a story
tips: Encourage creativity and humor
Can set themes like my weekend or my dream
Keep atmosphere light and fun
variants: Movie titles: Use emojis to represent movie names, others guess
Team collaboration: Multiple people collaborate to tell a complete story with emojis

title: Speed Networking
description: Participants pair up for 2-3 minute quick exchanges, then rotate partners. This game allows everyone to quickly meet multiple team members.
shortDescription: Pair up for quick exchanges, rotate partners
steps: Divide participants into two rows, facing each other standing or sitting
Each pair has 2-3 minutes to introduce and chat
Host keeps time, reminds when time is up
One row moves right one position, new partners
Continue chatting, repeat multiple rounds
Finally can share most memorable conversations
tips: Provide topic prompts like your hobbies or recent achievements
Keep pace tight to avoid awkward silences
Encourage active listening
variants: Online version: Use breakout room features
Themed version: Set different topics for each round

title: Brainstorm Challenge
description: Give the team a creative problem and generate as many solutions as possible within a time limit. This game stimulates creativity and teamwork.
steps: Host presents a creative problem (like how to make the office more fun)
Divide participants into small groups (3-5 people)
Give each group 10 minutes to brainstorm
Encourage any ideas, no judgment
Record all ideas
Each group shares their top 3 favorite ideas
Everyone votes to select the best creative idea
tips: Emphasize quantity over quality, encourage bold ideas
Prohibit criticizing or rejecting others' ideas
Can use sticky notes for easy organization and categorization
variants: Crazy ideas: Require the most outrageous, impractical ideas
Constraints: Add limitations like zero budget or only recycled materials

title: Would You Rather
description: Host presents would you rather A or B questions, participants choose and explain their reasoning. This game sparks interesting discussions and reveals values.
shortDescription: Choose between two options, share reasons
steps: Host prepares a series of would you rather questions
Present first question (like would you rather fly or be invisible)
Participants raise hands or move to different areas of room to show choice
Invite several participants to share their reasoning
Continue to next question
Can let participants suggest their own questions
tips: Choose interesting or thought-provoking questions
Avoid overly sensitive or controversial topics
Encourage humorous and creative answers
variants: Work-related: Questions related to work scenarios
Extreme choices: Present two equally undesirable options

title: Picture Story Chain
description: Participants take turns choosing pictures and telling part of a story, collaboratively creating a complete narrative. This game stimulates creativity and teamwork.
shortDescription: Take turns choosing pictures to tell story, create together
materials: Picture cards or online image library
steps: Prepare a series of random pictures (can be photos, illustrations, etc.)
First person chooses a picture and starts the story
Next person chooses another picture and continues the story
Each person tells for 1-2 minutes
Take turns until the story concludes
Discuss the creativity and team collaboration in the story
tips: Encourage creativity and humor
Remind participants to listen to previous content to keep story coherent
Can record or write down the story
variants: Themed story: Limit story type like sci-fi or fairy tale
Competition version: Multiple groups compete, vote for best story

title: Virtual Scavenger Hunt
description: Host lists a series of items, participants must find and show these items from home. This game is perfect for online meetings and quickly energizes the atmosphere.
shortDescription: Find specified items at home and show them
steps: Host prepares an item list (like something red or childhood photo)
Announce first item
Participants have 30-60 seconds to find it
Those who find it show the item and briefly introduce it
Continue to next item
Can keep score, fastest finder gets points
tips: Choose interesting items with stories
Control time, maintain pace
Encourage participants to share stories behind items
variants: Themed hunt: Limit theme like childhood memories or travel souvenirs
Creative hunt: Require finding most unique or creative items

title: One Word Story
description: Participants take turns saying one word to collaboratively create a story. This game tests reaction skills and creativity, quickly energizing the atmosphere.
shortDescription: Each person says one word, create story together
steps: Participants form a circle or sit in order
First person says one word to start story (like once)
Next person says one word to continue (like upon)
Take turns, each person can only say one word
Try to keep story coherent and interesting
Can set an ending point or let story end naturally
tips: Keep fast pace
Encourage creativity and humor
If story gets stuck, can restart
variants: Three word story: Each person says three words
Themed story: Limit story theme or type

title: Team Trivia
description: Host asks questions about team members or company, participants compete to answer. This game increases understanding among team members.
shortDescription: Answer questions about the team, increase understanding
steps: Host prepares questions about team members in advance
Can divide into small groups for competition
Host presents question
Participants or groups compete to answer
Correct answers earn points, wrong answers don't lose points
Finally tally scores and announce winner
tips: Questions should be interesting but not invasive of privacy
Can include company history, team achievements, etc.
Keep atmosphere light and fun
variants: Personal version: Each person submits questions about themselves in advance
Guess who: Based on descriptions, guess which team member

title: Compliment Circle
description: Participants form a circle, each person gives a sincere compliment to the person on their right. This game creates a positive atmosphere and strengthens team cohesion.
shortDescription: Give compliments to each other, create positive atmosphere
steps: Participants form a circle
Explain rules: each person gives a sincere compliment to person on their right
Compliments can be about work performance, personal qualities, or any positive aspect
Start with first person, proceed clockwise
Everyone gets a chance to give and receive compliments
After finishing, can share feelings
tips: Emphasize sincerity and specificity
Avoid empty compliments
Create warm and supportive atmosphere
Remind participants to listen and accept compliments
variants: Random compliments: Draw names to determine compliment recipient
Written compliments: Write on notes, share anonymously
